segments.text: Wednesday the 27th.
Wednesday the 27th.
Wednesday the 27th.
Today, chatting still with Dr. Dean Gage, and today we have him ready to begin service again as a faculty member at Texas A&M.
You returned from the University of Tennessee what year?
I returned in August of 1982.
And joined the Department of?
Well, actually, I became associate dean for academic and clinical programs.
That's right.
And I did have a tenured faculty position in the Department of Small Animal Medicine and Surgery.
My responsibilities were totally administrative.
And describe, as you understood them when you arrived, describe what your responsibilities were to be.
Well, I assure you they became somewhat different than when I arrived because so many different things needed a lot of change and upgrading put into it.
And the title really signified a few major areas of responsibility.
One was for
the entire Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital, and the second was all of the academic programs within the College of Veterinary Medicine.
And there were some real opportunities and real challenges, one of which was to completely reorganize the Veterinary Teaching Hospital

put it into the context of truly being a veterinary medical teaching hospital with all of the departments both clinical and basic science participating and to structure a hospital board that would reflect the different services and academic and research programs that would need to be a part of that kind of operation.
The second major responsibility was clearly in the academic arena of all of the student affairs, the academic program, the curriculum.
And at that point in time, we were in the process of coming up with a brand new curriculum and totally shelving the old curriculum

coming with a new one with a new schedule, of getting some of the departments to give up hours, which is never easy, and the students were already taking no less than 19 and up to 21 hours a semester.
So it was a terrifically heavy load for them anyway.
So those were the two big areas of responsibility and the two big areas of challenge.
How did that new curriculum, how did it come about?
Well, that was interesting because clearly I knew that in the dean's role that I had to take a lead and that it was going to take some tough, hard decision making to bring people to an agreement.
I knew that no one or not everyone would be happy.
There's no way to ever do that.
And no one ever wants to give up hours.
They simply want to pack more material into it.
So I laid down the guidelines and I went to Dean Shelton and I told him, I said, you've got to give me the authority
and really the leverage to be able to force some decisions.
And I'm going to get these people in a room.
We're going to set the guidelines, the rules, and start from a clean slate and build it from the bottom up.
And I told him it would take a lot of long, hard hours and long, long meetings.
And I purposely began to meet in the evening on a few of them.
So about 1130 at night, you begin to get a lot more consensus and agreement.
And when we finished, there was a real sense of accomplishment, an ownership, an excitement about having something new.
We were fortunate in that we had seen a lot of the new curriculums around the country.
I came from the University of Tennessee where we put a brand new curriculum in from scratch.
And quite frankly, I used that experience of starting from ground zero, throwing the old out.
We didn't have an old there, but throwing the old out here and starting from scratch.
And it was an exciting time for us, really.
As you look back now, who deserves credit for being very positive in helping bring those changes about?
Well, I think clearly Dean Shelton had a role in it because he had communicated to all the department heads that we had to do that.
And they had to be a part of it.
They had to support the entire college over an individual interest.
We have great cooperation among the department heads, too.
And I went to them in the dean's meetings and told them that I had to have their help and they had to be a part of it.
So it was a joint effort, a real team effort that met with, I think,

excitement because it was at a time where curricula around the nation were also changing and our leadership knew that we wanted to be at the forefront to do some things new and that we were already one of the leading veterinary medical colleges so this gave us an opportunity to even press forward in a higher visible role were there any other schools that had
already made these changes?

Many of the schools were either in the process of making changes or what really was before us was that there were seven new schools that came aboard within the last four or five years preceding that time.
So those schools came with no old curriculum.
They got to put a lot of new things in.
So that gave a real impetus for probably most every veterinary medical college in the nation to redo their curriculum.
In terms of what was dropped out, eliminated, or left behind, and what was introduced, what were the major changes?

The major changes, quite honestly, reflected where the profession was for that day and for really where it is now in the fact that the knowledge base, the expertise had both become so expanded over the last 25, 30 years
to the point that specialization was a real part of the profession.
And by that, I mean all the board certifications, you know, ophthalmology, radiology, surgery.
And I came from surgical specialty of being a diplomate of the American College of Veterinary Surgeons.
And others would go into a more narrow field such as biomedical research or one of the basic science areas.

So that it became very evident to us that we had to allow for some specialization within the curriculum itself to meet the needs and the demands of the profession and the public that was using the veterinary medical services.
Now, did this also reflect a shift in numbers of patients from large animal to small animal, from rural to urban?
It did to some degree mainly because there was a higher percentage and had been for several years of students that would go into a small animal practice versus the opportunities in large animal.

But what it did, it also allowed us to take the large animal tracks and to specialize more in equine or food animal or mixed practice and then move over into the small animal where they could spend additional hours in any of those areas that they might
elect or where they had a career interest.
So, yeah, very much that was reflected in what we did.
Give some examples, as you can recall it, of how you felt it was working, those changes.
Well, the changes were confirmed by the way the students began to register for some of the specialty tracks.
The overall

acceptance of the faculty and how that was accepted was something that we put in place from the beginning and that is that at the end of every semester I would have an evaluation of that semester at the end of every year that was completed for those students we'd have an evaluation among our students among our faculty separately of how we felt it was going and we had made a pact
or an agreement in advance that if we found that we had problems that we would go back and make adjustments.
And I promised the faculty that and the department heads on the front end.
We also did one other thing that I have always felt was a very positive step and that is that we would look at
state board results.

We would look at doing a survey one year, two years post-graduate to see if the students themselves saw an area of deficit or they had an area where they felt like they weren't prepared as they needed to be.
So we tried to put a feedback and accountability system in place and I told the faculty that
new curriculum would not be in concrete.
It would still be in process and still be mixing until we determined that we were accomplishing what we set out to do.
Can you give some examples of events, incidents, comments that demonstrated the differing opinions of people who liked the changes and those who didn't?

Well, most of the comments that we might get of people who didn't like the changes versus those who did came from those who probably had to give up hours and they were not getting to maybe share some of their personal interest as much as they would like.
A faculty member?
Faculty members.
We had no real problem with any of the student feedback because I think they felt generally
that they were well prepared.
One of the areas that has always been a criticism of most medical colleges has been that students did not know the public, the business side of it.
So we put an internship in, a short-term internship in, so that they would have actual experience on site out in the profession.
They get a lot of that in a veterinary teaching hospital for a full year.
That's not just a two semester, that is a full year of training.
And it is different though in a private practice or another type of specialty practice than what is at a teaching hospital such as the one at Texas A&M.
So we tried to bring that into it.
So we tried to correct all those things and the students accepted it readily.
Now, at this point, to get into the College of Veterinary Medicine as a student, the old two-year pre-vet program had become four.
That was history.
That had become four.
Every student that wanted to get into the College of Veterinary Medicine entered most often having already completed at least a baccalaureate and many times even a master's degree.
Now some of the real bright students might be in their fourth year of their baccalaureate degree and they would gain admission provided they finish the baccalaureate degree.
And then the old trimester program had become four years.
Had become four years.
We had moved from the three year, three trimester year
to the four-year curriculum.
As you look back now on those two changes, what were the pluses and if any minuses?
Well, the biggest plus was the removal of so much year-round burnout.
I always told students that it is not as much the complexity
of the content as it is the overwhelming pace and volume.
And when you go year round with very short breaks between a term, that is a tough, tough time.
The other thing that I saw was that it was probably easier on the faculty too because they had a summer to devote them to their other research activities and to go back and refresh
and to redo a lot of curriculum material.
When you're working year round with no breaks, the time factor for student and faculty really became an issue.
Compare the student body of the College of Veterinary Medicine at that point with the student body when you were a member of it.
Well, that's an interesting comparison.
Because as stated earlier, the first girl that ever went to veterinary college was in my class.
So there was one girl and 63 men.
And when I left the veterinary college in 1989, the student body was about 50, 55% women and 45, 50% men.
So that was a dramatic change.
The other major change I saw was
related to the work ethic and the difference in having the kind of study skills that I saw back earlier.
And that simply is reflective of the society, the affluence, where so many young men and women never had to work manually even,
as hard as they did back in the earlier times.

So most of the time when a student had trouble, it was because of the fact that they never had to work that hard, it was new to them, or they had not yet developed the kind of hard-working study skills that were absolutely required to just keep up with the pace, the volume of material that was going to be covered.
Were the students also different in their geographic and economic backgrounds?
Probably we had more from the urban areas starting in the probably even late 70s, mid to late 70s, and I think that trend is still there.
But there was still a great representation geographically from the entire state and a lot of rural areas too.
Describe the admissions process at that time.
The admissions process had not changed to a high degree.
with the exception that an aptitude test had been put in place.

So the students' actual performance, their overall GPA, their GPA in the sciences, their GPA in the last 45 semester credit hours were all taken into account as a very important predictor of whether or not they could handle the professional curriculum.
The aptitude test was also very important.
because a student that might not have applied themselves early but yet had tremendous intellect, that would help give them a little boost because we knew they could handle it.
But their own record was critically important.

At that time though, every student had to have an interview because it was very important that the selection admissions committee knew that that student had a motivation, they had checked out what the profession was,
they knew what they were going to get into, and they could demonstrate that they had the personal skills to really be a professional.
And there were people probably with significantly high grades that may not have got in because their personality profile, just their characteristics did not fit what was going to be required of them.
Do you remember in general what kind of a GPA?
The average GPA from top to bottom was always around a 3.4 and that means we had some with a 4.0 and a few down into the 3.2, 3.1.
The reason that it was a spread like that was the fact that some of the students who had gotten off to a bad start but yet had done very well in the last
45 semester credit hours, which was singled out in the higher level courses, would be given a little bit of a favorable evaluation because they were handling those harder courses at a better level.
They didn't come in high and go low.
They came in and then kept increasing in their GPA.
Can you share any examples of attempted outside interference to gain admission?
We had letters from every kind of political office that probably would be in the state and even national to give favorable treatment to certain students, but those were given no more weight.
than any letters of reference that the students were asked to have submitted on their behalf.
The students' academic performance and background and their own personal record constituted what the main selection was based on.
This is an editorial note to the typist.
One time in the

early 70s, probably 74, maybe 75, as dean of faculties, I was in President Williams' office, phone rang, and it was Oscar Wyatt, prominent Houstonian, calling in regard to the admission of a young man I believe was related to his secretary.
And as I recall, he apparently had promised her that he would see to it that this young man was admitted.
And this had not happened.
Mr. Wyatt was calling Dr. Williams to tell him to take care of it.
Dr. Williams had the material on his desk because he'd been expecting a call, and the student's record wasn't even marginal.
It was pitifully poor.
And he told Mr. Wyatt that he could not, in fairness to everyone else, set someone else aside and put that person in there.
I remember Mr. Wyatt getting louder and stronger in his voice.
And then he started cussing Dr. Williams.

and he ended up by saying i'm going to get you fired and then he used some real strong three and four letter word language and dr williams at first was frowning and then he started smiling as he hung up the phone uh... that for me was an example of some of the problems that administrators have to face when there are selective processes for admission
In comparing those years with your earlier years, how much more difficult was it for an applicant for admission to the College of Veterinary Medicine in your administrative years?
Actually, the admission was probably no more difficult because we were now taking 128 students and still had anywhere from four to 550
sometimes 600 applicants.
To contrast that, when I got in, 64 students and over 600 applicants.
And that really is what precipitated the increase in
the professional school enrollment, that the need was there and there were so many young men and women in Texas that wanted to go to veterinary college.
Do you have any recollection as to what year that jump in the admission number occurred?
It occurred probably in the early 60s.
Early 60s.
We had 600 that year.
But no, I'm talking about the number to be admitted.
Yes, because my class was the last class of 64.
The following year they went to 97 and then they went to 128.
At one time they had gotten up to 138 and then dropped it back and it stabilized at 128 for I presume now at least the last 20 years.
And during the years that you were close to the admissions process, about what percentage of the students admitted to Vet Medicine had been undergraduates at A&M?
Probably at least 50% of them had done at least part of their work here.
A good many had done all of it, but most of them knew that ultimately, since this was the only veterinary college in the state of Texas,
They wanted to get here.
What other schools were important sources for applicants?
That was pretty well distributed throughout the state.
You'd be surprised at the number from the University of Texas, Texas Tech, San Houston State, Southwest Texas, and San Marcos.
We had a number from Rice.
And it was pretty well distributed across the state.
Were we still in the contract with?
No, we had no contract with any other.
And we at that time only took 128 Texas residents.
Whereas now, I believe that the Veterinary College is taking 10

at large students from anywhere in the U.S. Am I correct in recalling that on occasion students from other states would move here, not go to college for a year, become a legal resident, and then apply?
That's exactly right.
In fact, the residency issue became very real in that they could not come to the state of Texas, be a student, and work part-time and become a Texas resident.

And it was clear to us when we'd look at the backgrounds of some of the students that they moved to the state and maybe worked a year or two, not enrolled in any college work at all in order to establish residency, then continue to take coursework and apply as a Texas resident.
And the reason for that was that this was such a great veterinary college, but also that tuition was so much less than most all of the other states.
That is no longer and was no longer the case about the time I left the College of Veterinary Medicine.
The tuition had begun to go up substantially.
Right, now you're in this role as Associate Dean for how long?
I was in that role from 1982 through 1988.
And how did your task change?
Before I tell you how that changed, I would like to tell you there were a couple of things that we did other than just the academics that I thought were very important to the future of the college.
One was that I went in to Dean Shelton and I told him, I said, George, this is not a formula kind of program.
Long term for the health and the advancement of this
College of Inherent Medicine.
We have to look at what we can do to get the funding to change that item similar to what is being done for the medical and dental schools in the state.
He said, I agree with you.
I've had discussions with the higher administration.
We've had so much turnover there that about the time I get someone up to speed on it, they have gone.
And he said, will you help me and let's go.
And I said, well, let's go.
Let's put it together.
Let's put the package together.
Let's go to the university administration, show them the benefit that it would have to them by taking us and putting us a line item separately funded like the medical and dental schools.
And I said, one other thing that I think is very important that we do, and that is that we designate
this entire complex as the Texas Veterinary Medical Center to give it the same public awareness as the Texas Medical Center in Houston, for instance.
Because I told him, I said, we're the only one in the state.
In all the complicated cases, they all come here.
And we are that.
So let's project our true identity so that we can get our funding on base, which will allow us
to develop our research programs and it will allow us to develop all the clinical specialties that we're going to need if we're going to be in a top five veterinary college.
So right after I had finished all of that, I had been offered the deanship at two other universities, but my heart was here at A&M and I wanted to see that veterinary college become the very best
And I had been interviewed for a couple of upper administrative positions at A&M.
I had even been recommended by a selection committee and was not picked by the upper level administrator at the time.
But Bill Mobley was executive vice chancellor right under Perry Atkinson and was named president of Texas A&M.
And I wrote Bill a letter indicating to him my background, my administrative background, and my interest.
And just sent my resume to him and said that if you have a position in your office or your administration where I could be a fit and make a difference, please keep me in mind.
And this was when he was first putting together his team.
And a few weeks went by and I get a call from him.
And I really did not know him except to see him.
And I go over and talk to him and he gives me some idea about a position that would be chief of staff and executive assistant to the president.
And it would also involve handling state affairs.
Well, I had

had a long-term interest in politics and legislative issues and had gone through the process of dealing with a couple of legislative sessions when we moved the veterinary college to a line item in the Texas Veterinary Medical Center.
So he then got back to me shortly afterwards, and on January 1, 1989, I moved to the president's office.

to become chief of staff and executive assistant to the president and handling just the chief of staff responsibilities in that office and a lot of the external liaison to the different constituents as well as state affairs.
Compare what you understood to be your assignment
to what it turned out to be.
Well, it was like most other responsibilities and jobs that I have had.
You take it with a written job description, but there's always one last job responsibility written on there which says, and all other assigned responsibilities.
And that became a huge expanded part of that position because he was a visionary.
and had so many programs that he wanted to put into the university to implement.

And I usually got the assignment of doing, I guess, kind of the strategic planning of meeting with people across campus, of pulling those programs together, of putting them into a sellable kind of proposal that would be a part of the whole university family.
and they could see the benefit in moving us toward where we wanted to go.
Our heart and our goal was for A&M to be a top 10 university, period.
And we were trying to visualize what it would take for us to become
